channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iraqi Envoy Calls on U.S. to Strengthen Relationship
item.description: The ambassador, Lukman Faily, said that the United States should be more generous in providing assistance but emphasized he did not advocate a resumed military presence.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chasing the Money for Families of Passengers on Missing Flight
item.description: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continues, Monica R. Kelly, an aviation accident attorney for Ribbeck Law based in Chicago, has been meeting with the families of the missing passengers to discuss compensation and, at times, act as a counselor.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica R. Kelly and other members of her firm, Ribbeck Law, based in Chicago, have been meeting with the families of passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: The Village Stadium, a Symbol of Power for Hungary’s Premier
item.description: Viktor Orban, the country’s prime minister, has been aggressive both politically and in the business world, and a new soccer stadium in his tiny hometown is testament to his rising ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new soccer stadium in Felcsut, Hungary is convenient for Viktor Orban, the prime minister: The house at right is his.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 4 Soldiers Killed in Chechnya
item.description: Four Russian servicemen were killed and seven were wounded when a bomb hit their vehicle in the North Caucasus republic of Chechnya, Russia’s Interior Ministry said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Illness Spreads at Factories
item.description: Scores of garment workers have fallen sick this week at factories in Cambodia, including two that produce clothing for the sportswear groups Puma and Adidas, workers and the companies said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: China: U.S. to Shun Joint Naval Drills
item.description: The United States will not send a fleet to take part in naval exercises that China is hosting this month, military officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Migrants Thwarted at Enclave
item.description: Spanish and Moroccan police on Thursday thwarted a new attempt by at least 100 African migrants to scale border fences and enter the Spanish enclave of Melilla.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Cancels Prisoner Release as Talks Hit Impasse
item.description: The decision was a response to a Palestinian push to join 15 international conventions and treaties, which Israel regarded as an unacceptable move.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Chad, Amid Criticism, Will Pull Troops From Force in Central Africa
item.description: The decision came after criticism that Chadian soldiers were siding with Muslim militias against Christians fighting a bloody sectarian conflict.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Mexico City Journal: With Instruments and Odes, Comforting Mexican Mourners
item.description: The Wolves of the Sierra, musicians who play songs at funerals in Mexico City, are part of a tradition of hiring musicians to celebrate the dead.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: At Quiet Rebel Base, Plotting an Assault on South Sudan’s Oil Fields
item.description: A rebel leader with a satellite phone, a touch-screen tablet and a copy of “Why Nations Fail” ponders the next step in a young country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: By JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Turkey Lifts Twitter Ban After Court Calls It Illegal
item.description: The social media site was unblocked after a two-week ban, following a ruling from the country’s highest court that the ban violated freedom of expression.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Talk of Freeing a Spy for Israel Stirs Old Unease for U.S. Jews
item.description: More and more Jews say the time to free Jonathan J. Pollard is long past, but they are unsure whether he should be used as a chit in a diplomatic transaction with Israel.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Lebanon Hosts Over a Million Who Fled Syria, U.N. Reports
item.description: United Nations officials call the influx a devastating milestone in the humanitarian crisis created by the Syrian civil war.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: For Many Germans, Pilots’ Walkout Crosses a Line
item.description: A three-day work stoppage by Lufthansa pilots appears to be breaking the unwritten rules of German workplace relations.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Lufthansa pilots are on a three-day strike, forcing the global airline to cancel about 3,800 flights.

item.title: South Sudan Urgently Needs Help to Stave Off Famine, U.N. Warns
item.description: The country needs food, water, seeds and farming tools in order to plant crops, a United Nations official said, or it will face the worst starvation in Africa since the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: About 3.7 million people are already at severe risk of starvation in South Sudan.

item.title: European Central Bank Hints at Bond-Buying Program
item.description: The bank left its benchmark rate at 0.25 percent, but its president, Mario Draghi, said the policy council had discussed quantitative easing.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, center, the European Central Bank's president, said inflation was expected to pick up in April.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 3
item.description: Medha Patkar, the Aam Aadmi Party candidate from Mumbai North-East constituency during an election campaign in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Medha Patkar, a social activist and the Aam Aadmi Party candidate from Mumbai North-East, receiving flowers from a supporter during an election campaign in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: In Afghanistan, a Campaign of Resilience
item.description: Barring last-minute catastrophe, Afghans will vote on Saturday with a turnout that the United Nations hopes will reach 50 percent.
item.dc:creator: By BRYAN DENTON

item.title: India Ink: India Ranks 102nd on Social Development Index
item.description: The Social Progress Index, a survey of a broad range of social development indicators of 132 countries, ranked India 102nd.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: India ranked 97th of 132 countries on nutrition and access to basic medical care.

item.title: India Ink: As Narendra Modi Rises, His Grip Over His Party Tightens
item.description: Senior Bharatiya Janata Party leaders have been shunted aside or expelled in recent weeks, set in motion by the growing clout of the party’s candidate for prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, prime ministerial candidate of the Bharatiya Janata Party, addressing an election rally in Itanagar, Arunachal Pradesh, on Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Reaction to the Supreme Court’s Campaign Finance Decision
item.description: The Supreme Court decision struck down limits on federal campaign contributions. It only concerned those from individuals. Federal law continues to ban contributions by corporations and unions.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ukraine Implicates Ex-President and Russia in Protesters’ Deaths
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities said on Thursday that former President Viktor F. Yanukovych and Russian security forces had been involved in plans that led to more than 100 deaths.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Former President Viktor F. Yanukovych reflected in a mirror on Wednesday in Rostov-on-Don, Russia.

item.title: DealBook: A Muddy Tract Now, but by 2020, China’s Answer to Wall St.
item.description: A largely empty expanse in Shenzhen is the setting for a financial experiment that could have a huge impact on the world’s second-largest economy. But so far it is just a bold blueprint.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The Qianhai special economic zone in Shenzhen

item.title: 2 Women Are Kidnapped From a Resort in Malaysia
item.description: The abductions appeared to be the work of insurgents from nearby islands of the southern Philippines who have been fighting the Philippine government.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and FLOYD WHALEY
